mn90:1.1.comm: The narrative of this sutta is entertainingly chaotic, with characters appearing and disappearing at random, many of whom are unknown or little-known elsewhere. This is a lifelike impression of how hard it is to maintain a rational dialogue among the comings and goings. Historically it gives a brief but telling character portrait of Viḍūḍabha, the ill-starred prince of Kosala.

mn90:1.2.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā uruññāyaṃ viharati kaṇṇakatthale migadāye.
mn90:1.2.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Ujuññā, in the deer park at Kaṇṇakatthala.
mn90:1.2.comm: Ujuññā was a Kosalan town at which discussed asceticism with the naked ascetic Kassapa in DN 8. | “Deer parks” were nature reservations where the animals were safe from hunters.

mn90:2.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena rājā pasenadi kosalo uruññaṃ anuppatto hoti kenacideva karaṇīyena.
mn90:2.1.eng: Now at that time King Pasenadi of Kosala had arrived at Ujuññā on some business.

mn90:2.2.pli: Atha kho rājā pasenadi kosalo aññataraṃ purisaṃ āmantesi:

mn90:2.3.pli: “ehi tvaṃ, ambho purisa, yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkama; upasaṅkamitvā mama vacanena bhagavato pāde sirasā vandāhi, appābādhaṃ appātaṅkaṃ lahuṭṭhānaṃ balaṃ phāsuvihāraṃ puccha:
mn90:2.3.eng: “Please, worthy man, go to the Buddha, and in my name bow with your head to his feet. Ask him if he is healthy and well, nimble, strong, and living comfortably.

mn90:2.4.pli: ‘rājā, bhante, pasenadi kosalo bhagavato pāde sirasā vandati, appābādhaṃ appātaṅkaṃ lahuṭṭhānaṃ balaṃ phāsuvihāraṃ pucchatī’ti;

mn90:2.6.pli: ‘ajja kira, bhante, rājā pasenadi kosalo pacchābhattaṃ bhuttapātarāso bhagavantaṃ dassanāya upasaṅkamissatī’”ti.
mn90:2.6.eng: ‘Sir, King Pasenadi of Kosala will come to see you today when he has finished breakfast.’”

mn90:2.7.pli: “Evaṃ, devā”ti kho so puriso rañño pasenadissa kosalassa paṭissutvā yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho so puriso bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
mn90:2.7.eng: “Yes, Your Majesty,” that man replied. He did as the king asked.

mn90:2.8.pli: “rājā, bhante, pasenadi kosalo bhagavato pāde sirasā vandati, appābādhaṃ appātaṅkaṃ lahuṭṭhānaṃ balaṃ phāsuvihāraṃ pucchati;

mn90:2.10.pli: ‘ajja kira, bhante, rājā pasenadi kosalo pacchābhattaṃ bhuttapātarāso bhagavantaṃ dassanāya upasaṅkamissatī’”ti.

mn90:3.1.pli: Assosuṃ kho somā ca bhaginī sakulā ca bhaginī:
mn90:3.1.eng: The sisters Somā and Sakulā heard this.
mn90:3.1.comm: These sisters were apparently both married to the King and, like his chief queen Mallikā, were devoted to the Buddha. Somā is perhaps the devout laywoman mentioned at AN 8.91–117:1.1, but is probably not the bhikkhunī of the same name mentioned at SN 5.2 and Thig 3.8. Sakulā likewise is probably not the same person as the bhikkhunī mentioned in Thig 5.7 and AN 1.242:1.1.

mn90:3.2.pli: “ajja kira rājā pasenadi kosalo pacchābhattaṃ bhuttapātarāso bhagavantaṃ dassanāya upasaṅkamissatī”ti.

mn90:3.3.pli: Atha kho somā ca bhaginī sakulā ca bhaginī rājānaṃ pasenadiṃ kosalaṃ bhattābhihāre upasaṅkamitvā etadavocuṃ:
mn90:3.3.eng: While the meal was being served, they approached the king and said,

mn90:3.4.pli: “tena hi, mahārāja, amhākampi vacanena bhagavato pāde sirasā vandāhi, appābādhaṃ appātaṅkaṃ lahuṭṭhānaṃ balaṃ phāsuvihāraṃ puccha:
mn90:3.4.eng: “Great king, since you are going to the Buddha, please bow in our name with your head to his feet. Ask him if he is healthy and well, nimble, strong, and living comfortably.”

mn90:3.5.pli: ‘somā ca, bhante, bhaginī sakulā ca bhaginī bhagavato pāde sirasā vandati, appābādhaṃ appātaṅkaṃ lahuṭṭhānaṃ balaṃ phāsuvihāraṃ pucchatī’”ti.

mn90:4.1.pli: Atha kho rājā pasenadi kosalo pacchābhattaṃ bhuttapātarāso yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho rājā pasenadi kosalo bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
mn90:4.1.eng: When he had finished breakfast, King Pasenadi went to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and said to him,

mn90:4.2.pli: “somā ca, bhante, bhaginī sakulā ca bhaginī bhagavato pāde sirasā vandati, appābādhaṃ appātaṅkaṃ lahuṭṭhānaṃ balaṃ phāsuvihāraṃ pucchatī”ti.
mn90:4.2.eng: “Sir, the sisters Somā and Sakulā bow with their heads to your feet. They ask if you are healthy and well, nimble, strong, and living comfortably.”

mn90:4.3.pli: “Kiṃ pana, mahārāja, somā ca bhaginī sakulā ca bhaginī aññaṃ dūtaṃ nālatthun”ti?
mn90:4.3.eng: “But, great king, couldn’t they get any other messenger?”

mn90:4.4.pli: “Assosuṃ kho, bhante, somā ca bhaginī sakulā ca bhaginī:
mn90:4.4.eng: So Pasenadi explained the circumstances of the message.

mn90:4.5.pli: ‘ajja kira rājā pasenadi kosalo pacchābhattaṃ bhuttapātarāso bhagavantaṃ dassanāya upasaṅkamissatī’ti.

mn90:4.6.pli: Atha kho, bhante, somā ca bhaginī sakulā ca bhaginī maṃ bhattābhihāre upasaṅkamitvā etadavocuṃ:

mn90:4.7.pli: ‘tena hi, mahārāja, amhākampi vacanena bhagavato pāde sirasā vandāhi, appābādhaṃ appātaṅkaṃ lahuṭṭhānaṃ balaṃ phāsuvihāraṃ puccha—

mn90:4.8.pli: somā ca bhaginī sakulā ca bhaginī bhagavato pāde sirasā vandati, appābādhaṃ appātaṅkaṃ lahuṭṭhānaṃ balaṃ phāsuvihāraṃ pucchatī’”ti.

mn90:4.9.pli: “Sukhiniyo hontu tā, mahārāja, somā ca bhaginī sakulā ca bhaginī”ti.
mn90:4.9.eng: The Buddha said, “May the sisters Somā and Sakulā be happy, great king.”

mn90:5.1.pli: Atha kho rājā pasenadi kosalo bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
mn90:5.1.eng: Then the king said to the Buddha,

mn90:5.2.eng: “I have heard, sir, that the ascetic Gotama says this:

mn90:5.3.pli: ‘natthi so samaṇo vā brāhmaṇo vā yo sabbaññū sabbadassāvī aparisesaṃ ñāṇadassanaṃ paṭijānissati, netaṃ ṭhānaṃ vijjatī’ti.
mn90:5.3.eng: ‘There is no ascetic or brahmin who will ever claim to be all-knowing and all-seeing, to know and see everything without exception: that is not possible.’
mn90:5.3.comm: The Buddha was well aware of the fact that people did, in fact, make such claims, as he discussed them several times (eg. MN 76:21.1). He just thought the claims were wrong. One unique detail of the phrasing here is that it is in future tense (also used below at MN 90:8.5). The implication seems to be that not only is it the case that no-one currently makes such claims, but that no-one ever will in the future. | Compare with other statements on omniscience at MN 14:17.3 and MN 71:5.2.

mn90:5.4.pli: Ye te, bhante, evamāhaṃsu: ‘samaṇo gotamo evamāha—natthi so samaṇo vā brāhmaṇo vā yo sabbaññū sabbadassāvī aparisesaṃ ñāṇadassanaṃ paṭijānissati, netaṃ ṭhānaṃ vijjatī’ti; kacci te, bhante, bhagavato vuttavādino, na ca bhagavantaṃ abhūtena abbhācikkhanti, dhammassa cānudhammaṃ byākaronti, na ca koci sahadhammiko vādānuvādo gārayhaṃ ṭhānaṃ āgacchatī”ti?
mn90:5.4.eng: Do those who say this repeat what the Buddha has said, and not misrepresent him with an untruth? Is their explanation in line with the teaching? Are there any legitimate grounds for rebuttal and criticism?”

mn90:5.5.pli: “Ye te, mahārāja, evamāhaṃsu: ‘samaṇo gotamo evamāha—natthi so samaṇo vā brāhmaṇo vā yo sabbaññū sabbadassāvī aparisesaṃ ñāṇadassanaṃ paṭijānissati, netaṃ ṭhānaṃ vijjatī’ti; na me te vuttavādino, abbhācikkhanti ca pana maṃ te asatā abhūtenā”ti.
mn90:5.5.eng: “Great king, those who say this do not repeat what I have said. They misrepresent me with what is false and untrue.”

mn90:6.1.pli: Atha kho rājā pasenadi kosalo viṭaṭūbhaṃ senāpatiṃ āmantesi:
mn90:6.1.eng: Then King Pasenadi addressed General Viḍūḍabha,
mn90:6.1.comm: The King’s son and heir, whose disastrous reign heralded the destruction of the Sakyans and the collapse of the Kosalan empire.

mn90:6.2.pli: “ko nu kho, senāpati, imaṃ kathāvatthuṃ rājantepure abbhudāhāsī”ti?
mn90:6.2.eng: “General, who introduced this topic of discussion to the royal compound?”

mn90:6.3.eng: “It was Sañjaya, great king, the brahmin of the Ākāsa clan.”
mn90:6.3.comm: Ākāsa here is the Pali form of Sanskrit āgastya, the clan descending from the Vedic seer Agastya.

mn90:7.1.pli: Atha kho rājā pasenadi kosalo aññataraṃ purisaṃ āmantesi:
mn90:7.1.eng: Then the king addressed a man,

mn90:7.2.pli: “ehi tvaṃ, ambho purisa, mama vacanena sañjayaṃ brāhmaṇaṃ ākāsagottaṃ āmantehi:
mn90:7.2.eng: “Please, worthy man, in my name tell Sañjaya that

mn90:7.4.pli: “Evaṃ, devā”ti kho so puriso rañño pasenadissa kosalassa paṭissutvā yena sañjayo brāhmaṇo ākāsagotto tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā sañjayaṃ brāhmaṇaṃ ākāsagottaṃ etadavoca:
mn90:7.4.eng: “Yes, Your Majesty,” that man replied. He did as the king asked.

mn90:8.1.pli: Atha kho rājā pasenadi kosalo bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
mn90:8.1.eng: Then the king said to the Buddha,

mn90:8.2.pli: “siyā nu kho, bhante, bhagavatā aññadeva kiñci sandhāya bhāsitaṃ, tañca jano aññathāpi paccāgaccheyya.
mn90:8.2.eng: “Sir, might the Buddha have spoken in reference to one thing, but that person believed it was something else?

mn90:8.3.pli: Yathā kathaṃ pana, bhante, bhagavā abhijānāti vācaṃ bhāsitā”ti?
mn90:8.3.eng: How then do you recall making this statement?”

mn90:8.4.pli: “Evaṃ kho ahaṃ, mahārāja, abhijānāmi vācaṃ bhāsitā:
mn90:8.4.eng: “Great king, I recall making this statement:

mn90:8.5.pli: ‘natthi so samaṇo vā brāhmaṇo vā yo sakideva sabbaṃ ñassati, sabbaṃ dakkhiti, netaṃ ṭhānaṃ vijjatī’”ti.
mn90:8.5.eng: ‘There is no ascetic or brahmin who will ever know all and see all simultaneously: that is not possible.’”
mn90:8.5.comm: Consciousness is conditioned, so any instance of knowing depends on a particular stimulus. At MN 76:52.5 the Buddha discusses the related point of whether knowledge is continuous, illustrating it with a simile of an amputee.

mn90:8.6.pli: “Heturūpaṃ, bhante, bhagavā āha; saheturūpaṃ, bhante, bhagavā āha:

mn90:8.7.pli: ‘natthi so samaṇo vā brāhmaṇo vā yo sakideva sabbaṃ ñassati, sabbaṃ dakkhiti, netaṃ ṭhānaṃ vijjatī’ti.

mn90:9.1.eng: Sir, there are these four classes:

mn90:9.3.pli: Imesaṃ nu kho, bhante, catunnaṃ vaṇṇānaṃ siyā viseso siyā nānākaraṇan”ti?
mn90:9.3.eng: Is there any difference between them?”

mn90:9.6.pli: Imesaṃ kho, mahārāja, catunnaṃ vaṇṇānaṃ dve vaṇṇā aggamakkhāyanti—
mn90:9.6.eng: “Of the four classes, two are said to be preeminent—

mn90:9.8.eng: That is, when it comes to bowing down, rising up, greeting with joined palms, and observing proper etiquette.”
mn90:9.8.comm: The Buddha acknowledges the social distinctions between the classes.

mn90:10.1.eng: “Sir, I am not asking you about this life,

mn90:10.2.eng: but about the life to come.”

mn90:10.5.pli: Imesaṃ nu kho, bhante, catunnaṃ vaṇṇānaṃ siyā viseso siyā nānākaraṇan”ti?

mn90:10.6.eng: “Great king, there are these five factors that support meditation.

mn90:10.8.pli: Idha, mahārāja, bhikkhu saddho hoti, saddahati tathāgatassa bodhiṃ:
mn90:10.8.eng: It’s when a mendicant has faith in the Realized One’s awakening:

mn90:10.9.pli: ‘itipi so bhagavā arahaṃ sammāsambuddho vijjācaraṇasampanno sugato lokavidū anuttaro purisadammasārathi satthā devamanussānaṃ buddho bhagavā’ti;
mn90:10.9.eng: ‘That Blessed One is perfected, a fully awakened Buddha, accomplished in knowledge and conduct, holy, knower of the world, supreme guide for those fit for training, teacher of gods and humans, awakened, blessed.’

mn90:10.10.pli: appābādho hoti appātaṅko samavepākiniyā gahaṇiyā samannāgato nātisītāya nāccuṇhāya majjhimāya padhānakkhamāya;
mn90:10.10.eng: They are rarely ill or unwell. Their stomach digests well, being neither too hot nor too cold, but just right, and fit for meditation.

mn90:10.11.pli: asaṭho hoti amāyāvī yathābhūtaṃ attānaṃ āvikattā satthari vā viññūsu vā sabrahmacārīsu;
mn90:10.11.eng: They’re not devious or deceitful. They reveal themselves honestly to the Teacher or sensible spiritual companions.

mn90:10.12.pli: āraddhavīriyo viharati akusalānaṃ dhammānaṃ pahānāya, kusalānaṃ dhammānaṃ upasampadāya, thāmavā daḷhaparakkamo anikkhittadhuro kusalesu dhammesu;
mn90:10.12.eng: They live with energy roused up for giving up unskillful qualities and embracing skillful qualities. They’re strong, staunchly vigorous, not slacking off when it comes to developing skillful qualities.

mn90:10.13.pli: paññavā hoti udayatthagāminiyā paññāya samannāgato ariyāya nibbedhikāya sammādukkhakkhayagāminiyā—
mn90:10.13.eng: They’re wise. They have the wisdom of arising and passing away which is noble, penetrative, and leads to the complete ending of suffering.

mn90:10.14.eng: These are the five factors that support meditation.

mn90:10.17.pli: Te cassu imehi pañcahi padhāniyaṅgehi samannāgatā;
mn90:10.17.eng: If they had these five factors that support meditation,

mn90:10.18.pli: ettha pana nesaṃ assa dīgharattaṃ hitāya sukhāyā”ti.
mn90:10.18.eng: that would be for their lasting welfare and happiness.”

mn90:11.3.pli: Te cassu imehi pañcahi padhāniyaṅgehi samannāgatā;
mn90:11.3.eng: If they had these five factors that support meditation,

mn90:11.4.pli: ettha pana nesaṃ, bhante, siyā viseso siyā nānākaraṇan”ti?
mn90:11.4.eng: would there be any difference between them?”

mn90:11.5.eng: “In that case, I say it is the disparity of their efforts in meditation.

mn90:11.6.pli: Seyyathāpissu, mahārāja, dve hatthidammā vā assadammā vā godammā vā sudantā suvinītā, dve hatthidammā vā assadammā vā godammā vā adantā avinītā.
mn90:11.6.eng: Suppose there was a pair of elephants or horses or oxen in training who were well tamed and well trained. And there was a pair who were not tamed or trained.

mn90:11.7.eng: What do you think, great king?

mn90:11.8.pli: ye te dve hatthidammā vā assadammā vā godammā vā sudantā suvinītā, api nu te dantāva dantakāraṇaṃ gaccheyyuṃ, dantāva dantabhūmiṃ sampāpuṇeyyun”ti?
mn90:11.8.eng: Wouldn’t the pair that was well tamed and well trained perform the tasks of the tamed, and reach the level of the tamed?”

mn90:11.10.pli: “Ye pana te dve hatthidammā vā assadammā vā godammā vā adantā avinītā, api nu te adantāva dantakāraṇaṃ gaccheyyuṃ, adantāva dantabhūmiṃ sampāpuṇeyyuṃ, seyyathāpi te dve hatthidammā vā assadammā vā godammā vā sudantā suvinītā”ti?
mn90:11.10.eng: “But would the pair that was not tamed and trained perform the tasks of the tamed and reach the level of the tamed, just like the tamed pair?”

mn90:11.12.pli: “Evameva kho, mahārāja, yaṃ taṃ saddhena pattabbaṃ appābādhena asaṭhena amāyāvinā āraddhavīriyena paññavatā, taṃ vata assaddho bahvābādho saṭho māyāvī kusīto duppañño pāpuṇissatīti—netaṃ ṭhānaṃ vijjatī”ti.
mn90:11.12.eng: “In the same way, there are things that must be attained by someone with faith, health, integrity, energy, and wisdom. It’s not possible for a faithless, unhealthy, deceitful, lazy, witless person to attain them.”

mn90:12.1.pli: “Heturūpaṃ, bhante, bhagavā āha; saheturūpaṃ, bhante, bhagavā āha.

mn90:12.2.eng: Sir, there are these four classes:

mn90:12.4.pli: Te cassu imehi pañcahi padhāniyaṅgehi samannāgatā te cassu sammappadhānā;
mn90:12.4.eng: If they had these five factors that support meditation, and if they practiced rightly,

mn90:12.5.pli: ettha pana nesaṃ, bhante, siyā viseso siyā nānākaraṇan”ti?
mn90:12.5.eng: would there be any difference between them?”

mn90:12.6.pli: “Ettha kho nesāhaṃ, mahārāja, na kiñci nānākaraṇaṃ vadāmi—yadidaṃ vimuttiyā vimuttiṃ.
mn90:12.6.eng: “In that case, I say that there is no difference between the freedom of one and the freedom of the other.

mn90:12.7.pli: Seyyathāpi, mahārāja, puriso sukkhaṃ sākakaṭṭhaṃ ādāya aggiṃ abhinibbatteyya, tejo pātukareyya;
mn90:12.7.eng: Suppose a person took dry teak wood and lit a fire and produced heat.

mn90:12.8.pli: athāparo puriso sukkhaṃ sālakaṭṭhaṃ ādāya aggiṃ abhinibbatteyya, tejo pātukareyya;
mn90:12.8.eng: Then another person did the same using sāl wood,

mn90:12.9.pli: athāparo puriso sukkhaṃ ambakaṭṭhaṃ ādāya aggiṃ abhinibbatteyya, tejo pātukareyya;

mn90:12.10.pli: athāparo puriso sukkhaṃ udumbarakaṭṭhaṃ ādāya aggiṃ abhinibbatteyya, tejo pātukareyya.
mn90:12.10.eng: while another used wood of the cluster fig.

mn90:12.11.eng: What do you think, great king?

mn90:12.12.pli: siyā nu kho tesaṃ aggīnaṃ nānādāruto abhinibbattānaṃ kiñci nānākaraṇaṃ acciyā vā acciṃ, vaṇṇena vā vaṇṇaṃ, ābhāya vā ābhan”ti?
mn90:12.12.eng: Would there be any difference between the fires produced by these different kinds of wood, that is, in the flame, color, or luminosity?”

mn90:12.14.pli: “Evameva kho, mahārāja, yaṃ taṃ tejaṃ vīriyā nimmathitaṃ padhānābhinibbattaṃ, nāhaṃ tattha kiñci nānākaraṇaṃ vadāmi—yadidaṃ vimuttiyā vimuttin”ti.
mn90:12.14.eng: “In the same way, when fire has been churned by energy and produced by effort, I say that there is no difference between the freedom of one and the freedom of the other.”
mn90:12.14.comm: Nimmathita refers to the process whereby a flame is produced by “churning” with a fire-drill. See Rig Veda 3.23.1a, 3.29.12a, 6.48.5, 8.48.6a, etc.

mn90:13.1.pli: “Heturūpaṃ, bhante, bhagavā āha; saheturūpaṃ, bhante, bhagavā āha.

mn90:13.2.comm: The sense of atthi devā (“do gods survive?”) is made clear by the following discussion. Compare atthi attā (“the self survives”) at SN 44.10:1.3 and MN 2:8.2 in the same sense. In such cases the verb atthi implies continued existence in a future life. We find a similar usage in Kaṭha Upaniṣad 1.20, where Naciketa wonders what happens to a man after he dies, as “some say he survives, while others say he does not survive” (astīty eke nāyam astīti caike).

mn90:13.3.comm: Questions with atthi (“exists”, “survives”) about the self and rebirth are routinely met indirectly. Here the Buddha asks for clarification; at SN 44.10:1.3 he avoids answering; at MN 100:42.5 he answers in an oblique fashion. The reason for this seems to be that the verb atthi conveys the metaphysical implication of “eternal existence”. The king clarifies that he wants to know what happens when a god passes away, showing that he is asking about rebirth rather than eternal existence.

mn90:13.5.pli: “Yadi vā te, bhante, devā āgantāro itthattaṃ yadi vā anāgantāro itthattaṃ”?
mn90:13.5.eng: “Whether those gods come back to this place or not.”

mn90:13.6.pli: “Ye te, mahārāja, devā sabyābajjhā te devā āgantāro itthattaṃ, ye te devā abyābajjhā te devā anāgantāro itthattan”ti.
mn90:13.6.eng: “Those gods who are afflicted come back to this place, but those who are unafflicted do not come back.”
mn90:13.6.comm: This builds on the discussion with Pasenadi in MN 88:10.6, where “hurtful” or “afflicted” (sabyābajjha) behavior leads to suffering, elsewhere described as rebirth in a “hurtful” realm (eg. MN 57:8.2).

mn90:14.1.pli: Evaṃ vutte, viṭaṭūbho senāpati bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
mn90:14.1.eng: When he said this, General Viḍūḍabha said to the Buddha,

mn90:14.2.pli: “ye te, bhante, devā sabyābajjhā āgantāro itthattaṃ te devā, ye te devā abyābajjhā anāgantāro itthattaṃ te deve tamhā ṭhānā cāvessanti vā pabbājessanti vā”ti?
mn90:14.2.eng: “Sir, will the gods who are afflicted topple or expel from their place the gods who are unafflicted?”
mn90:14.2.comm: In a few words we learn a lot about how Viḍūḍabha sees himself: he is an afflicted god.

mn90:14.4.pli: “ayaṃ kho viṭaṭūbho senāpati rañño pasenadissa kosalassa putto;
mn90:14.4.eng: “This General Viḍūḍabha is King Pasenadi’s son,

mn90:14.5.eng: and I am the Buddha’s son.

mn90:14.6.pli: Ayaṃ kho kālo yaṃ putto puttena manteyyā”ti.
mn90:14.6.eng: Now is the time for one son to confer with another.”

mn90:14.7.pli: Atha kho āyasmā ānando viṭaṭūbhaṃ senāpatiṃ āmantesi:

mn90:14.8.pli: “tena hi, senāpati, taññevettha paṭipucchissāmi; yathā te khameyya tathā naṃ byākareyyāsi.
mn90:14.8.eng: “Well then, general, I’ll ask you about this in return, and you can answer as you like.

mn90:14.10.pli: yāvatā rañño pasenadissa kosalassa vijitaṃ yattha ca rājā pasenadi kosalo issariyādhipaccaṃ rajjaṃ kāreti, pahoti tattha rājā pasenadi kosalo samaṇaṃ vā brāhmaṇaṃ vā puññavantaṃ vā apuññavantaṃ vā brahmacariyavantaṃ vā abrahmacariyavantaṃ vā tamhā ṭhānā cāvetuṃ vā pabbājetuṃ vā”ti?
mn90:14.10.eng: As far as the dominion of King Pasenadi of Kosala extends, where he rules as sovereign lord, can he topple or expel from that place any ascetic or brahmin, regardless of whether they are good or bad, or whether or not they are genuine spiritual practitioners?”

mn90:14.11.pli: “Yāvatā, bho, rañño pasenadissa kosalassa vijitaṃ yattha ca rājā pasenadi kosalo issariyādhipaccaṃ rajjaṃ kāreti, pahoti tattha rājā pasenadi kosalo samaṇaṃ vā brāhmaṇaṃ vā puññavantaṃ vā apuññavantaṃ vā brahmacariyavantaṃ vā abrahmacariyavantaṃ vā tamhā ṭhānā cāvetuṃ vā pabbājetuṃ vā”ti.
mn90:14.11.comm: Bho (“worthy”) is typically used by brahmins; he also uses it in reference to the king below.

mn90:14.13.pli: yāvatā rañño pasenadissa kosalassa avijitaṃ yattha ca rājā pasenadi kosalo na issariyādhipaccaṃ rajjaṃ kāreti, tattha pahoti rājā pasenadi kosalo samaṇaṃ vā brāhmaṇaṃ vā puññavantaṃ vā apuññavantaṃ vā brahmacariyavantaṃ vā abrahmacariyavantaṃ vā tamhā ṭhānā cāvetuṃ vā pabbājetuṃ vā”ti?
mn90:14.13.eng: As far as the dominion of King Pasenadi does not extend, where he does not rule as sovereign lord, can he topple or expel from that place any ascetic or brahmin, regardless of whether they are good or bad, or whether or not they are genuine spiritual practitioners?”

mn90:14.14.pli: “Yāvatā, bho, rañño pasenadissa kosalassa avijitaṃ yattha ca rājā pasenadi kosalo na issariyādhipaccaṃ rajjaṃ kāreti, na tattha pahoti rājā pasenadi kosalo samaṇaṃ vā brāhmaṇaṃ vā puññavantaṃ vā apuññavantaṃ vā brahmacariyavantaṃ vā abrahmacariyavantaṃ vā tamhā ṭhānā cāvetuṃ vā pabbājetuṃ vā”ti.

mn90:14.16.eng: Have you heard of the gods of the thirty-three?”

mn90:14.19.pli: Idhāpi bhotā raññā pasenadinā kosalena sutā devā tāvatiṃsā”ti.
mn90:14.19.eng: and so has the worthy King Pasenadi.”

mn90:14.21.pli: pahoti rājā pasenadi kosalo deve tāvatiṃse tamhā ṭhānā cāvetuṃ vā pabbājetuṃ vā”ti?
mn90:14.21.eng: Can King Pasenadi topple or expel from their place the gods of the thirty-three?”

mn90:14.22.pli: “Dassanampi, bho, rājā pasenadi kosalo deve tāvatiṃse nappahoti, kuto pana tamhā ṭhānā cāvessati vā pabbājessati vā”ti?
mn90:14.22.eng: “King Pasenadi can’t even see the gods of the thirty-three, so how could he possibly topple or expel them from their place?”

mn90:14.23.pli: “Evameva kho, senāpati, ye te devā sabyābajjhā āgantāro itthattaṃ te devā, ye te devā abyābajjhā anāgantāro itthattaṃ te deve dassanāyapi nappahonti; kuto pana tamhā ṭhānā cāvessanti vā pabbājessanti vā”ti?
mn90:14.23.eng: “In the same way, general, the gods who are afflicted can’t even see the gods who are unafflicted, so how could they possibly topple or expel them from their place?”
mn90:14.23.comm: Compare the discussion in the Jain Viyāhapaṇṇatti 6.9.144, where pure gods are beyond the scope of impure gods.

mn90:15.1.pli: Atha kho rājā pasenadi kosalo bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
mn90:15.1.eng: Then the king said to the Buddha,

mn90:15.2.comm: If Pasenadi does not know Ānanda, this must be a very early encounter, perhaps his first.

mn90:15.4.eng: “A joy he is, and a joy he seems!

mn90:15.5.pli: Heturūpaṃ, bhante, āyasmā ānando āha; saheturūpaṃ, bhante, āyasmā ānando āha.
mn90:15.5.eng: What Venerable Ānanda says seems reasonable.

mn90:15.6.eng: But sir, does a divinity survive?”

mn90:15.9.pli: “Yadi vā so, bhante, brahmā āgantā itthattaṃ, yadi vā anāgantā itthattan”ti?
mn90:15.9.eng: “Whether that Divinity comes back to this place or not.”

mn90:15.10.pli: “Yo so, mahārāja, brahmā sabyābajjho so brahmā āgantā itthattaṃ, yo so brahmā abyābajjho so brahmā anāgantā itthattan”ti.
mn90:15.10.eng: “A divinity who is afflicted comes back to this place, but one who is unafflicted does not come back.”

mn90:16.1.pli: Atha kho aññataro puriso rājānaṃ pasenadiṃ kosalaṃ etadavoca:
mn90:16.1.eng: Then a certain man said to the king,

mn90:16.2.eng: “Great king, Sañjaya, the brahmin of the Ākāsa clan, has come.”

mn90:16.3.pli: Atha kho rājā pasenadi kosalo sañjayaṃ brāhmaṇaṃ ākāsagottaṃ etadavoca:

mn90:16.4.pli: “ko nu kho, brāhmaṇa, imaṃ kathāvatthuṃ rājantepure abbhudāhāsī”ti?
mn90:16.4.eng: “Brahmin, who introduced this topic of discussion to the royal compound?”

mn90:16.7.eng: “It was Sañjaya, great king, the brahmin of the Ākāsa clan.”
mn90:16.7.comm: Not only does Viḍūḍabha exhibit poor leadership by blaming a subordinate, he is evidently lying about it.

mn90:17.1.pli: Atha kho aññataro puriso rājānaṃ pasenadiṃ kosalaṃ etadavoca:
mn90:17.1.eng: Then a certain man said to the king,

mn90:17.3.pli: Atha kho rājā pasenadi kosalo bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
mn90:17.3.eng: So the king said to the Buddha,

mn90:17.4.pli: “sabbaññutaṃ mayaṃ, bhante, bhagavantaṃ apucchimhā, sabbaññutaṃ bhagavā byākāsi;
mn90:17.4.eng: “Sir, I asked you about omniscience, and you answered.

mn90:17.5.pli: tañca panamhākaṃ ruccati ceva khamati ca, tena camhā attamanā.
mn90:17.5.eng: I endorse and accept this, and am satisfied with it.

mn90:17.6.pli: Cātuvaṇṇisuddhiṃ mayaṃ, bhante, bhagavantaṃ apucchimhā, cātuvaṇṇisuddhiṃ bhagavā byākāsi;
mn90:17.6.eng: I asked you about purification in the four classes,

mn90:17.7.pli: tañca panamhākaṃ ruccati ceva khamati ca, tena camhā attamanā.

mn90:17.8.pli: Adhideve mayaṃ, bhante, bhagavantaṃ apucchimhā, adhideve bhagavā byākāsi;

mn90:17.9.pli: tañca panamhākaṃ ruccati ceva khamati ca, tena camhā attamanā.

mn90:17.10.pli: Adhibrahmānaṃ mayaṃ, bhante, bhagavantaṃ apucchimhā, adhibrahmānaṃ bhagavā byākāsi;
mn90:17.10.eng: and about divinities, and you answered in each case.

mn90:17.11.pli: tañca panamhākaṃ ruccati ceva khamati ca, tena camhā attamanā.

mn90:17.12.pli: Yaṃ yadeva ca mayaṃ bhagavantaṃ apucchimhā taṃ tadeva bhagavā byākāsi;
mn90:17.12.eng: Whatever I asked the Buddha about, he answered.

mn90:17.13.pli: tañca panamhākaṃ ruccati ceva khamati ca, tena camhā attamanā.
mn90:17.13.eng: I endorse and accept this, and am satisfied with it.

mn90:17.14.pli: Handa ca dāni mayaṃ, bhante, gacchāma;
mn90:17.14.eng: Well, now, sir, I must go.

mn90:17.15.eng: I have many duties, and much to do.”

mn90:17.16.eng: “Please, great king, go at your convenience.”

mn90:18.1.pli: Atha kho rājā pasenadi kosalo bhagavato bhāsitaṃ abhinanditvā anumoditvā uṭṭhāyāsanā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā padakkhiṇaṃ katvā pakkāmīti.
mn90:18.1.eng: Then King Pasenadi approved and agreed with what the Buddha said. Then he got up from his seat, bowed, and respectfully circled the Buddha, keeping him on his right, before leaving.
